column13:
RAZ-ber-ee
A soft fruit resembling a red or blackberry.

Plate: A "plate" typically refers to a flat, shallow, and round or oval dish that is used to serve individual portions of food. It is the standard item on which a main course or a portion of a meal is placed. Plates are usually made of various materials, such as ceramic, porcelain, glass, or plastic.   Dish: "Dish" is a broader term that encompasses any container or vessel used for serving or holding food. It includes plates but can also refer to bowls, platters, serving dishes, and even cookware like casseroles or baking dishes. "Dish" is a more general term that covers a wider range of food-serving containers.

column7: In Portuguese, the word "peixe" can be used for both the living animal (fish) and the prepared food (fish as a meal).

column8: an espresso with a drop of milk
column9: /æn ɛˈsprɛsoʊ wɪð ə drɒp əv mɪlk/
column10: /æn ɛˈsprɛsəʊ wɪð ə drɒp əv mɪlk/

column13: This is the name for a very short shot of espresso, what might be known as a ristretto in other countries: normal quantity of grounds but extracted with about half the amount of water. If you've been to Rome, you'll surely recognize the style.
column20: Así se llama un shot muy corto de espresso, lo que en otros países podría llamarse ristretto: cantidad normal de café molido pero extraído con aproximadamente la mitad de agua.

column7: Café aguado, con leche, servido en un vaso alto con una cuchara alta. <br><br>La gente lo toma mientras desayuna, y después acostumbra a pedir un café más cargado.
En Portugal la sopa es de vegetales y tiene una consistencia cremosa. Se acostumbra siempre en la comida y la cena.
